Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Biometric IoT system for First Responders
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to improve the safety of firefighters through the research and development of a real-time, wearable sensor system comprising a biometric heads-up display and accompanying analysis tools. This device collects each firefighter?s vital signs in real-time, displays the information via a heads-up display, and alerts them if they are in danger. Simultaneously, it will send the data to authorized officials for real-time strategic decision-making. By receiving access to life-critical information, the commander can make informed decisions on the allocation of key resources during the hectic scene of an emergency. Firefighting is chaotic; every year over one million firefighters risk their lives to protect others. Over 50% of the deaths in firefighting are caused by overexertion and stress, which can induce heart attacks as well as other serious medical issues. Furthermore, around 70,000 firefighting injuries occur each year. The proposed system aims to reduce the amount of firefighting injuries and subsequent costs, which totaled $7.8 billion in 2004, but the design is not limited to firefighting. The proposed system can be easily adapted to serve similar occupations such as military personnel and industrial workers.

The proposed project may be the first to monitor the effects of the extreme nature of fire incidents with physiological stressors and provide this data in real-time. The proposed technology could significantly improve the occupational safety of firefighters and further enhance the scientific knowledge created by studying their physiological states. The proposed project includes three main technical objectives: 1) The research and development of a rugged wearable system that will monitor the physiology of firefighters in real-time. 2) The research and development of a machine learning algorithm to identify key markers that will indicate the exertion and stamina levels of first responders in chaotic environments. 3) The development of a long-range radio system capable of transmission within large urban structures comprising various possible interferences. All three objectives will consist of two pilot studies with an intermittent development phase in between, where feedback from the first pilot study will be incorporated into both the hardware and software. It is expected that the outcomes of this project will demonstrate a significant reduction in firefighter injuries, paving the way for a clear return on investment for the partnering fire departments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Firefighting is chaotic. Every year over one million firefighters in the United States risk their lives to protect others. The number one cause of deaths and injuries in firefighting is overexertion and heat stress. Over 50% of the deaths in firefighting are caused by overexertion and stress, which can induce heart attacks as well as other serious medical issues. Furthermore, around 80,800 firefighting injuries occur each year, each costing $97,000 on average. In total, injuries from firefighting totaled $7.8 billion in 2004.

Current firefighting equipment does not include access to biometric information in real-time, which could warn decision-makers when firefighters are overexerting themselves. Because of this, incident command and fire officials outside the fire have to rely on firefighters self-reporting their physiology in situations where talking and seeing is difficult, if not impossible. This is especially unreliable considering firefighter’s “never back down” attitude. Firefighting is inherently susceptible to overexertion in part due to firefighters’ passion to push their limits, and without biometric data there is no way of knowing where those limits are and when they are exceeded. During this NSF Phase I, FireHUD developed a biometric IoT system to address these issues.

Throughout the grant period, FireHUD conducted extensive customer discovery and found significant demand for its biometric monitoring system — the BioTrac Platform. FireHUD welcomed all comments —  negative or positive — but mostly received substantial support and interest. At the “Firefighter Physiological Monitoring Technology Summit” held by the National Fallen Firefighter Foundation (NFFF) at the end of March 2018, FireHUD gathered detailed feedback on its proposed mask-mounted device and found that the fire department representatives at the summit would much prefer an arm or wrist-worn device. This advice was echoed by several other experts in the fire service and led to the development of FireHUD’s current arm-worn device.

Over the Summer of 2018, the FireHUD team worked diligently to create prototypes of the arm-worn collection device that would be able to withstand the harsh conditions that is expected of firefighter equipment. In September of 2018, FireHUD created the first batch of prototypes to be tested at pilot sites. The newly developed device is designed to be expressly rugged and function in an ultra-passive manner requiring very little user interaction. The device can be worn on either the wrist or arm, knows when to turn on automatically, and has a radio range of up to five miles. The attached image displays the BioTrac Platform containing the new arm-worn device.

In parallel with the development and prototyping of the hardware, FireHUD also made large improvements to the software powering the web application — most notably upgrades to the user interface, the addition of new features, and the introduction of cloud algorithms. Over the course of the year, much of the underlying technology in the software application was adapted based on user feedback. The main objectives for the software team included: improvements to the user interface, the addition of alerting and overexertion algorithms, improving scalability and usability, and the addition of more management tools. All of the Phase I software objectives were completed as well as additional goals over the course of the grant period.

After the new prototypes were created, FireHUD was ready to deploy a new pilot site. This deployment began in August 2018 with the Barrow County Fire Department. Barrow County wanted to use the prototype devices for monitoring their recruit class. The process of training new firefighters includes coursework on the theory of firefighting, as well as extensive physical training and conditioning. FireHUD observed the BioTrac Platform in use several times throughout the training program, as well as tested the new core body temperature algorithm. This pilot study was overall very successful. The recruits used the platform every day throughout the duration of the 12-week class.

During this Phase I study, FireHUD achieved its main objectives for the research and development of a real-time, IoT biometric system. FireHUD was greatly aided by the guidance of many firefighters, researchers, and mentors during Phase I and is grateful for their help. Going forward, FireHUD aims to further improve the technology of its BioTrac Platform and to put this technology in the hands of our first responders to significantly reduce line of duty injuries and deaths caused by cardiac arrest and overexertion.
